item.title: Simple math checking
item.dc:creator: @whattehp406 whattehp406
item.description:
@whattehp406 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:10, topic:533475”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=652268.msg4370802#msg4370802 date=1380590908]
PEMDAS : Parenthesis, Exponents, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction (Please Excuse My Dope Ass Swag / Please Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally)

4 * (567) * 89 * (78 + 890) * 6 / 100
4 * (567) * 89 * 968 * 6 / 100
4 * 567 * 89 * 968 * 6 / 100
1868 * 89 * 968 * 6 / 100
166252 * 968 * 6 / 100
160931936 * 6 / 100
965591616 / 100
9655916.16
[/quote]
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y9h1oqv21Vs&hd=1
This.[/quote]It’s pemdas and then left to right.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple math checking
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:15, topic:533475”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=652268.msg4370853#msg4370853 date=1380600869]
Actually, the order of operations is entirely correct. This isn’t to say that it is the correct way of solving an equation in order, as there is no correct way of doing that, hence why parenthesis were made. If you were to say PEMDAS always applies, you’re wrong. If you say to solve a problem using the order of operations, PEMDAS is, and always will be, correct. However, if it specifies a different hierarchy of operators, you’d be using that one (obviously). To say PEMDAS is wrong shows a complete lack of understanding of why it was made in the first place.
[/quote]
Did you watch the video and not just the image?
It doesn’t say that PEMDAS, BODMAS, PIMDAS… is wrong, just bad. The goal should be unambiguity and understanding the math, not just relying on a six letter word.[/quote]
In order to do PEMDAS one must understand the math; it isn’t bad, either. There is actually no possible way for it to be ‘bad’ as it is a means for completion. You also can’t simply rely on a six letter word, nor should any equations be made for you to require you to rely on the six letter word. Simply stated, it is a replacement for equations that have a lack of parenthesis.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple math checking
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

eyeownyew:

Actually, the order of operations is entirely correct. This isn’t to say that it is the correct way of solving an equation in order, as there is no correct way of doing that, hence why parenthesis were made. If you were to say PEMDAS always applies, you’re wrong. If you say to solve a problem using the order of operations, PEMDAS is, and always will be, correct. However, if it specifies a different hierarchy of operators, you’d be using that one (obviously). To say PEMDAS is wrong shows a complete lack of understanding of why it was made in the first place.

Did you watch the video and not just the image?
It doesn’t say that PEMDAS, BODMAS, PIMDAS… is wrong, just bad. The goal should be unambiguity and understanding the math, not just relying on a six letter word.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple math checking
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

Not really.
Try reading up on the order of operations, it comes in handy in places just like this.

4 * (567) * 89 * (78 + 890 ) * 6 / 100

First, you look at the parenthesis and solves those. So you’ll end up with:
4 * 567 * 89 * 968 * 6 / 100

Then, it’s simply a matter of going across from left to right as the rest is multiplication and division.
2268 * 89 * 968 * 6 / 100
Then:
201852 * 968 * 6 / 100
Then:
195392736 * 6 / 100
Then:
1172356416 / 100

Your answer:
11723564.16

Read full topic
